clinical_study.brief_title: Short-term Effects of Live Music in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Short-term Effects of Live Pentatonic Music on Physiological Parameters in Preterm Infants - A Randomized Controlled Trial With Crossover Design

lead_sponsor.agency: ARCIM Institute Academic Research in Complementary and Integrative Medicine

clinical_study.source: ARCIM Institute Academic Research in Complementary and Integrative Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of pentatonic live music on physiological parameters in preterm infants.

primary_outcome.time_frame: physiological parameters are measured twice over a period of 2 hours and 15 minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Physiological parameters are measured twice over a period of 2 hours and 15 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gestational age 26-34 weeks; no use of CPAP (Continous Positive Airway Pressure) or any other form of mechanical ventilation; signed informed consent of the parents
Exclusion Criteria:
- Heart defect or known cardiac arrhythmia; other diseases of the preterm and newborn period (including infections and chromosomal aberrations) which make an additional diagnostic and therapeutic intervention unacceptable; detection of deafness (TEOAE, transitory evoked otoacoustic emission)

reference.citation: Arnon S, Shapsa A, Forman L, Regev R, Bauer S, Litmanovitz I, Dolfin T. Live music is beneficial to preterm infants in the neonatal intensive care unit environment. Birth. 2006 Jun;33(2):131-6.
Standley JM. A meta-analysis of the efficacy of music therapy for premature infants. J Pediatr Nurs. 2002 Apr;17(2):107-13.

clinical_study.keyword: Preterm infants, music, Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU)
